round_data.prompt:
You and another agent have to negotiate a division of items between the two of you.
    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 1 units of item 1, 2 units of item 2, 3 units of item 3, 3 units of item 4, 2 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 42 for item 1, 67 for item 2, 6 for item 3, 45 for item 4, 87 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 503. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 67. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.98, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.
    
 Negotiation history:

Current offer on the table (the amount of each item being offered to you): None

        What is your action? As the first player, your available actions are:
        - WALK to walk away
        - A list of numbers [n1, n2, ...] representing your initial offer (what you give to Player 2)
round_data.response:
Step 1: Assess our information. We control the first move in round 1 and we know our own per‐unit values:
 • Item 1: 42 (1 unit)
 • Item 2: 67 (2 units)
 • Item 3: 6 (3 units)
 • Item 4: 45 (3 units)
 • Item 5: 87 (2 units)
If we took everything we’d get 503. But we also have an outside option of 67, so any agreement must exceed that. In addition, Player 2 (whose values are unknown but drawn uniformly from 1 to 101) will compare our offer to what they expect if they wait (their outside offer and later bargaining gains discounted by γ = 0.98).

Step 2: We want a proposal that—if accepted—yields us high total value while giving Player 2 “just enough” that they prefer accepting versus waiting. Since our interests differ (ranking items by our own values), we wish to keep very “valuable” items (for us) while offering items that give up little value on our side.

Step 3: Look at our “least‐valuable” items. For us the ordering is roughly: 
 • Item 3 (only 6 per unit) is very un‐valuable,
 • then item 1 (42 per unit) and item 4 (45 per unit),
 • with item 2 (67 per unit) and especially item 5 (87 per unit) being most precious.
A “fair” split – in expectation from Player 2’s perspective – would give them roughly half of the total “expected” value. (If all per‐unit values averaged about 51 for Player 2, then the total for them would be roughly 561 and a fair share would be about 280–281.) In units that means giving them roughly 5 or 6 units out of 11. We want to give the opponent 6 “units” – but choose those that cost us little.

Step 4: A natural offer is to give Player 2:
 • All 1 unit of item 1,
 • All 3 units of item 3, and 
 • 2 out of the 3 available units of item 4.
That adds up to 1 + 3 + 2 = 6 total units. This offer likely gives Player 2 an “expected” value of about 6 × 51 ≈ 306—comfortably above what they might expect from waiting, while we keep the items we value much more (item 2 and item 5 plus 1 unit of item 4).

Step 5: Let’s check our own payoff with this proposal. We would receive:
 • All units of item 2: 2 × 67 = 134,
 • The remaining unit of item 4: 1 × 45 = 45,
 • All units of item 5: 2 × 87 = 174.
Our total value becomes 134 + 45 + 174 = 353, which is very good compared to our outside offer of 67.

Step 6: As our initial action (when no offer is on the table), we must submit an offer specifying what we “give” to Player 2. Following the negotiation protocol, our offer is represented as a list of five numbers (for items 1 through 5).

Thus, we choose to offer Player 2:
 Item 1: 1 unit
 Item 2: 0 units
 Item 3: 3 units
 Item 4: 2 units
 Item 5: 0 units

This balanced offer rewards Player 2 with a reasonably attractive “expected” share while allowing us to keep the items that are most valuable to us.

Final answer in the required format:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 3, 2, 0]}

    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals.

    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.

round_data.response:
I will begin by “thinking aloud” about how best to start. Although I do not know Player 2’s exact per‐unit values or their private outside offer, I do know the following:

• There are 16 total units distributed as follows:
  – item 1: 5 units
  – item 2: 3 units
  – item 3: 4 units
  – item 4: 3 units
  – item 5: 1 unit

• My own per‐unit values are: item 1 = 88, item 2 = 96, item 3 = 25, item 4 = 56, and item 5 = 87.
  My complete “package” is worth 1083 (i.e. 5·88 + 3·96 + 4·25 + 3·56 + 1·87 = 1083),
  and my outside offer is 540.

• Player 2’s values are drawn uniformly in [1,101] so (on average) each unit is worth roughly 51 to them.
  Their outside offer is drawn (privately) from 1 up to their total—but (by symmetry) we expect their “reservation” value to be roughly half of the total (around 408 in expectation).

Since this is round 1 the outcome is undiscounted (gamma^(0)=1). I want to get a deal as soon as possible at a high value. In “splitting the pie” I want to keep most of the items that I highly value and “sacrifice” the items that are less valuable to me. In my case item 3 is quite “cheap” (only 25 in value per unit) so giving those away will cost me less while—if Player 2’s average value is around 51 per unit—still giving them a decent “share.”

One natural idea is to try to give Player 2 roughly 8 units in total (since 8 units × 51 ≈ 408, roughly matching a likely fallback for Player 2). Which 8 units should I give up? My aim is to minimize my own loss. Clearly I want to keep as many of item 1 (88 per unit), item 2 (96) and item 5 (87) as possible, and sacrifice the “cheaper‐to‐me” types first.

Looking at my list:
 – Item 3 (value 25 each) is the cheapest; giving up all 4 units costs me little.
 – Next, among the remaining items the ones I value more (item 4 is 56, item 1 is 88, and item 5 is 87). Item 4 is the next “cheaper” of these.
  I have 3 units of item 4; giving these all up would add 3 units.
That totals 4 + 3 = 7 units. I need one more unit to reach 8.

For the “last unit” I choose between item 1, item 2, or item 5. Item 2 is very valuable (96) so I won’t use that. Between item 1 (88) and item 5 (87) the slightly lower is item 5, so I give that unit too.

Thus, my offer to Player 2 is:
 • 0 units of item 1 (keep all 5)
 • 0 units of item 2 (keep all 3)
 • 4 units of item 3 (all gone)
 • 3 units of item 4 (all gone)
 • 1 unit of item 5 (all gone)

That means my “own share” would be:
 • item 1: 5, item 2: 3, item 3: 0, item 4: 0, item 5: 0.
My value for that is 5×88 + 3×96 = 440 + 288 = 728.

Player 2, on the other hand, would receive 8 units (4 + 3 + 1) which on average would yield about 8×51 = 408—roughly what one might expect from their outside offer. (In a full equilibrium analysis one might want to offer a slight “bonus” to ensure they accept rather than hold out, but as an initial offer in round 1 it appears reasonable.)

Thus, my chosen first move is to propose the offer that gives Player 2:
 [0, 0, 4, 3, 1]

I now state my action in the required JSON format.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 4, 3, 1]}

I’ll explain my reasoning briefly. My own “total‐value” for all items is 587, and my private outside option is 507. That means that if no deal is reached I get 507 – almost the entire full‐value of the items. In a deal I must assign to myself items whose total (my own private evaluations) comes to more than 507 in order to improve on my fallback. But since 587–507=80, the “surplus” I can gain from a deal (i.e. the extra value above my disagreement) is only 80. In a multilateral negotiation the “price” for persuading the other side (Player 2) to accept a deal is that I’d have to “pay” them a share of the items. In order to make a deal acceptable to Player 2 the offer must give them a bundle whose value to them is at least as high as their own outside option. Given that Player 2’s value per unit is drawn (independently) uniformly from 1 to 101 the expected unit‐value is about 51; and with the full set of items their total value would be around 1071 so that on average their outside offer is quite high (roughly half, about 535). 

Because I can “afford” only to lose the equivalent of 80 in my own evaluation—and because even “cheap” items (those whose cost to me is small) are usually still worth around 51 to Player 2—I cannot assemble an offer (a division of the items) that gives Player 2 an expected value high enough to beat their likely outside option while simultaneously leaving me with more than 507. (For example, if I try to “buy” Player 2’s acceptance using items I value little—say all of item 4 and some of item 5—I can only get at most 6 units in total worth me 66 points; yet from Player 2’s perspective that bundle would be worth only about 6×51 ≈306, well below their fallback value.) 

Given that any deal I try to propose in round 1 would force me to “pay” too much—even though I could improve my own share a bit if Player 2 agreed, the opponent is likely to reject and force me into my outside option of 507—I conclude that it is best not to try a deal in these circumstances. 

Therefore, my action in round 1 is to WALK.

{"action": "WALK"}

I first check what I would “get” if I accepted the current offer. The offer on the table would give me:  
• Item 1: 5 units at 7 each → 35  
• Item 2: 1 unit at 21 each → 21  
• Item 3: 4 units at 21 each → 84  
• Item 4: 0 units → 0  
• Item 5: 0 units → 0  
Total gross value = 35 + 21 + 84 = 140.  

Because we are in round 2 the discount factor is γ^(r–1) = 0.98^(2–1) = 0.98, so the present‐value of that deal would be 140 × 0.98 ≈ 137.2.  

By contrast, my private outside offer is 426 – and if I were to walk away I’d secure that amount with certainty. (The outcome of a walk is not discounted.)  

Although I have the possibility to make a counteroffer, any deal reached in round 2 would have its gross “pie” discounted by 0.98. That means if I want to be at least as well off as my outside option, I must secure a gross value of at least about 435 (since 435 × 0.98 ≈ 426.3). In effect, to get even a marginal improvement over my guaranteed outside option I would have to insist on keeping nearly all of the items (losing at most 665 – 435 = 230 in gross value). In a full‐information negotiation one might try to “squeeze” the other player by giving up only the items I value least – but here I have no certainty about Player 2’s private values or how much they must be given to agree. (Note that the current offer from Player 2, which gave me only 140 in gross value, is far below what I’d need and would give Player 2 a much larger share.)  

Given that the current offer gives me only about 137 and that even an aggressive counteroffer that leaves me barely above my outside option would run the risk of being rejected (forcing the negotiation into a next round with extra discounting or even ending the game), my safe and rational decision is not to continue bargaining.  

Therefore, I choose to WALK away from the negotiation.

Although I don’t know their exact values or outside offer, a typical assumption is that on average Player 2’s total value would be comparable to mine (around 1326 for the full bundle), and their outside option would average roughly half that (around 660–665).

For instance, estimated “fair” total for P2 might ideally be around 663. Allocating fewer units of the lower–valued item 5 risks dropping below that threshold.

I will explain my reasoning briefly. My aim is to “anchor” the negotiation with a demanding offer so that—even if we eventually reach an agreement—the deal gives me a present‐value (undiscounted here, in round 1) that is at least as good as my disagreement payoff of 433. (My total value from all items is 590, so I can “afford” to give up at most 590–433 = 157 points according to my own private values.) At the same time I know that several items are “cheap” for me relative to their likely (unknown) worth for Player 2. In my private evaluation item 1 is very precious (value 82 each) and item 3 is decent (32 each) while items 2 and 4 are relatively low‐value (both 17 each) and item 5 (30 each) is only modestly valued by me although on average Player 2 (whose per‐unit values are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101) would expect roughly 51 per unit. Thus, if I want to “protect” my own high-value items I can plan to keep all of items 1 and 3 and give up full item 2 and–if needed–all of item 4 (3 units) plus a small number of item 5 units. (In a fully “fair” split these extra units would have to be “bought” by Player 2 in order to get an expected overall value near what his outside option might be; indeed if Player 2’s expected overall value (if he got everything) were about 816 then his outside offer (roughly uniformly drawn from [1, total]) would average near 408. But because I must guarantee myself at least 433 the best I can do is to try a “demanding” proposal which gives me a discounted share above 433—even though it may be too little for Player 2 relative to his expectations. I’m in a position where if no deal is reached I get 433; hence I may “insist” on a division that nets me more than that while leaving Player 2 only a few items (which admittedly may be too low for him—and indeed he may well counter‐offer later).

I therefore propose the following initial offer. I give Player 2 the entire available quantity of item 2 (1 unit) and item 4 (3 units) and a small “concession” on item 5 (2 out of 6 units). I keep all of item 1 (3 units) and all of item 3 (3 units) and keep the other 4 units of item 5. (Thus my share is worth 3×82 + 3×32 + 4×30 = 246 + 96 + 120 = 462, safely above 433, while Player 2’s “bundle” consists of 1 unit of item 2, 3 of item 4 and 2 of item 5.) 

Thus my round 1 action is to make a counteroffer with the offer array:
  [0, 1, 0, 3, 2]

My final answer is therefore:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 1, 0, 3, 2]}

I’ll explain my reasoning briefly. My own “pie” (the total item‐value for me) is 706. (For example, I get 3×38 = 114 from item 1, 5×30 = 150 from item 2, 5×49 = 245 from item 3, 3×1 = 3 from item 4, and 2×97 = 194 from item 5; adding up gives 706.) I also know that if I “walk” I’m guaranteed 381. That means any deal I eventually accept must net me at least 381 (after discounting, though we’re in round 1 so discounting is 1). At the same time I want the offer to be acceptable to my opponent (Player 2) who has his own private outside option and likely assigns different per‐unit values. Because I know my own values, I can “concede” items that have low value to me but could be more attractive to him. For example, item 4 is almost worthless to me (value 1 per unit) so giving him all of item 4 (all 3 units) is a low “cost” concession while it might be appealing from his side if he happens to have a higher unit value for that item.

I also want to leave myself with a margin above my 381 reservation. One natural idea is to “split” the total items roughly in a 50/50 manner from my perspective. (A pure equal split of value would give me 353 – which is below 381 – so I must retain a bit more than half of my own total‐value “pie.”)

I therefore looked for a division where I give Player 2 a bundle whose value (from my view) is not too high but “looks” decent, while I keep at least 381 for myself. One candidate that comes out is to give Player 2:
 • 1 unit of item 1 (so I keep 2, worth 2×38 = 76)
 • 1 unit of item 2 (so I keep 4, worth 4×30 = 120)
 • 3 units of item 3 (so I keep 2, worth 2×49 = 98)
 • all 3 units of item 4 (worth 3×1 = 3 for me, but a full concession on that low‐value item)
 • 1 unit of item 5 (so I keep 1, worth 1×97 = 97)

Then my own allotment is worth 76 + 120 + 98 + 0 + 97 = 391, which beats my outside offer of 381. (Player 2’s “share” by my numbers would be 1×38 + 1×30 + 2×49 + 0 + 1×97 = 38 + 30 + 98 + 0 + 97 = 263. True, I don’t know his actual values—but by conceding the entire item 4 (and only a little extra on a couple of other items) I’m “buying” some goodwill from his perspective, especially if he happens to value item 4 much more than I do.)

Although many divisions are possible when you have private values and outside options, this offer is aggressive but leaves me several points above my reservation while giving my opponent a “package” that might be acceptable (and might give him the chance to improve it in later rounds if needed).

I’ve thought through the numbers at length. My own total‐value if I took everything would be 1670, but my “reservation” (outside offer) guarantees me 1376. In any division the two of us might agree on, I must do at least as well as that 1376. On the other hand, to “buy” Player 2’s buy‐in (so that they get at least as good as their own outside offer) the deal must hand over so many items that—even if I were to allocate the “best” items for myself—the number of items given to Player 2 would be high (roughly 13 or so out of 25 total units) and that would force my bundle (even if chosen optimally according to my private values) to be much less than my 1376. (For example, if I kept my 12 very “valuable” items from my perspective I would get around 1080 value; even if I took 13 items I could barely get above 1150. Only by keeping 17 or more items could I exceed 1376—but then Player 2 would get only 8 items, well below what they might expect on average from a full pie.) 

In short, any “fair‐enough” offer that would tempt Player 2 to accept would leave me with less than my outside offer. Since the discount factor is 0.98 but we are in round 1 and my outside is already extremely good from my viewpoint, a rational, self‐interested Player 1 will not risk any agreement when walking away already guarantees 1376. 

Thus, in round 1 the best action for me is to WALK away.

Thus, if I offer them items whose total “count” (when their unit value is about 51) sums to at least 9 units (9×51 ≈ 459) many will find that acceptable compared to their outside alternative.
